The Western Pomeranian city has been the capital of the Vorpommern-Rügen district since the 2011 district reforms. It is the fourth-largest city of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern and

column1: The city of Stralsund is located in northeastern Germany in the region of Western Pomerania in the state of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern. Stralsund is located south west of Rügen (which is also Germany's largest island). It is separated by a body of water named the Strelasund.
Its annual precipitation is 656 mm (25.8 inches) and comparatively low
column2: falling within the lowest third of all precipitation values in Germany. The driest month is February; the most precipitation falls in July. The precipitation varies relatively moderately throughout the year. Only 40% of weather stations in Germany exhibit lower seasonal variation.

column1: The city lies on the sound of Strelasund
column2: a strait of the Baltic Sea. Its geographic proximity to the island of Rügen
column3: whose only fixed link to the mainland
column4: the Strelasund Crossing
column5: runs between Stralsund and the village of Altefähr
column6: has given Stralsund the sobriquet "Gateway to the Island of Rügen" (Tor zur Insel Rügen). Stralsund is located close to the Western Pomerania Lagoon Area National Park.

column2: Frankenteich and Moorteich. The three ponds and the Strelasund lend the Old Town
column3: the original settlement site and historic center of the city
column4: a protected island ambience. The highest point of the city is the Galgenberg ("Gallows Hill") on its western approaches.

column1: In the Middle Ages the Stralsund area formed part of the West Slavic Principality of Rügen. At that time the Dänholm isle and fishing village
column2: both at the site of the latter city
column3: were called Strale or Stralow
column4: Polabian for "arrow" (this meaning underlies the city's coat of arms
column5: which shows an arrow). (The full Polabian name can be rendered in Polish (one of the Slavic languages closest to Polabian) as Strzałów).The village also had a ferry to the island of Rügen. In 1168 the Principality of Rügen became part of Kingdom of Denmark.

column1: In the course of German Ostsiedlung
column3: gentry and merchants were invited to settle in the principality
column4: and they eventually populated the Strale settlement. Merchants from other countries as well as locals were attracted to the area and made up one third of the settlement's population. The Danish navy used the isle as well. When the settlement had grown to town size
column5: prince Wizlaw I of Rügen granted Lübeck law to "our town Stralow" in 1234
column6: although a significant settlement had existed long before the formal founding. In 1240
column7: when the prince gave additional land to the town

column1: The success of the settlement challenged the powerful Free City of Lübeck
column2: which burnt Stralsund down in 1249. Afterwards the town was rebuilt with a massive town wall having 11 town gates and 30 watchtowers. The Neustadt
column3: a town-like suburb
column4: had merged with Stralsund by 1361. Schadegard
column5: a nearby twin town to Stralsund also founded by Wizlaw I
column7: served as the principal stronghold and enclosed a fort. It was given up and torn down by 1269 under pressure from the Stralsund Bürger.

column1: In 1293 Stralsund became a member of the Hanseatic League. A total of 300 ships flying the flag of Stralsund cruised the Baltic Sea in the 14th century. In 1325 the Principality of Rügen became part of the Duchy of Pomerania
column2: Stralsund however maintained a considerable independence.

column1: In the 17th century opposing forces in the Thirty Years' War fought over Stralsund. In the Battle of Stralsund (1628)
column2: the Imperial (Catholic) forces commanded by Albrecht von Wallenstein besieged the city after the council refused to accept the Capitulation of Franzburg of November 1627. Stralsund resisted with Danish and Swedish support. The Swedish garrison in Stralsund was the first on German soil in history. With the Treaty of Stettin (1630)
column3: the city became one of two major Swedish forts in the Duchy of Pomerania
column4: alongside Stettin (now Szczecin
column5: Poland).After the war
column6: the Peace of Westphalia (1648) and the Treaty of Stettin (1653) made Stralsund part of Swedish Pomerania. Lost to Brandenburg in the Battle of Stralsund (1678)
column7: it reverted to Sweden in the Treaty of Saint-Germain-en-Laye (1679). In the Great Northern War in 1715 Charles XII led the defence of Stralsund for a year against the united European armies. Stralsund remained under Swedish control until the Battle of Stralsund (1807)
column8: when Napoleon Bonaparte's army occupied it. Seized by Ferdinand von Schill's freikorps in 1809
column9: it subsequently reverted to French control
column10: with Schill killed in action. With the Congress of Vienna (1815)
column11: Stralsund became a part of the Prussian Province of Pomerania and the seat of a government region resembling the former Swedish Pomerania.

column1: Following the First World War Stralsund suffered the same sort of political unrest and unemployment that afflicted much of Germany. In May 1919 Stralsund workers clashed with police
column2: and martial law was declared. In the early 1920s the Independent Social Democratic Party (USPD) became the strongest party in Stralsund
column3: but its political fortunes waned rapidly
column4: and in September 1922 it reunited with the Social Democratic Party (SPD).

column1: In the national parliamentary election of May 1924
column2: the conservative German National People's Party (DNVP) polled 8
column3: 547 votes in Stralsund
column4: the SPD 3
column7: 825 and the German People's Party (DVP) of Foreign Minister Gustav Stresemann 1
column10: Hitler's National Socialists made rapid gains in the late 1920s
column11: and by the time of the last free national election in July 1932 the Nazis polled twice as many votes in Stralsund as the SPD.

column3: and a naval training base opened on the nearby island of Dänholm. In World War II the city was subjected to repeated Allied bombing. Attacks by the U.S. Army Air Forces in 1944 killed some 800 Stralsunders and destroyed an estimated 8
column4: 000 dwellings. The 354th Rifle Division of the Red Army occupied Stralsund on April 28
column5: 1945 – 10 days before the end of the war in Europe. Approximately half its population had fled.

column1: During the period of the German Democratic Republic (GDR)
column2: Stralsund saw the construction of numerous Plattenbau prefabricated apartment blocks. Its economic life centered on the now state-owned shipyard
column3: which largely focussed on building ships for the Soviet Union.

column2: the city's historic old town was thoroughly restored
column3: and Communist-era apartment blocks were renovated and upgraded. In 2002 the old towns of Stralsund and Wismar
column4: some 120 km to the west

column6: and thereafter specialized in constructing container ships.

column1: Old Town (Altstadt)The centre of Stralsund has a wealth of historic buildings. Since 1990
column2: large parts of the historic old town have been renovated with private and public capital
column3: and with the support of foundations. As a result of the contempt for historic buildings in East Germany many houses were threatened by ruin. The Old Town in particular offers a rich variety of historic buildings
column4: with many former merchants' houses
column5: churches
column6: streets and squares. Of more than 800 listed buildings in Stralsund
column7: more than 500 are designated as individual monuments in the Old Town. In twenty years
column8: from the Wende (turning point) in 1990 to November 2010
column11: including 363 individual monuments. Because of its historical and architectural significance
column12: in 2002 Stralsund's old town together with the old town of Wismar were added to entitled the UNESCO World Cultural Heritage list as the "Historic Centres of Stralsund and Wismar".

column1: The Gothic abbey of St. Anne and St. Bridget (Kloster St. Annen und Brigitten) in Schillstrasse was established around 1560 from the merger of the abbey of St. Anne (1480) and the double abbey of Mariakron (1421).
The Abbey of St. Jürgen (Kloster St. Jürgen am Strande) on Mönchstrasse was mentioned in 1278 for the first time. It served in the 14th century as an old people's home. In 1743 a new building
